body:
I've seen a lot of upvoted threads complaining about the prevalence of politics on this site recently (whether that matters has already been discussed to death), but with the relatively high rep requirements for creating a guild, I'm wondering whether there's a bit of a catch 22 situation here:

- For an apolitical person to create a guild, they need to build rep by posting and receiving upvotes.

- The threads and comments which tend to generate rep quickly are political, and anyone who isn't interested in participating will have a long slog ahead of them - especially if they're migrating from Reddit and don't want to 'play the game' to pick up from where they left off.

Does anyone else think it would draw more users if it was easier to make guilds, or is that just sacrificing quality in a rush to the finish line?

Also is it possible for a person who *does* meet rep requirements to create a guild on someone's behalf then hand over full ownership? I might try starting a thread for 'kickstarter' guild requests if so and see how that goes.

  • For an apolitical person to create a guild, they need to build rep by posting and receiving upvotes.

  • The threads and comments which tend to generate rep quickly are political, and anyone who isn't interested in participating will have a long slog ahead of them - especially if they're migrating from Reddit and don't want to 'play the game' to pick up from where they left off.

Does anyone else think it would draw more users if it was easier to make guilds, or is that just sacrificing quality in a rush to the finish line?

Also is it possible for a person who does meet rep requirements to create a guild on someone's behalf then hand over full ownership? I might try starting a thread for 'kickstarter' guild requests if so and see how that goes.

body:
I disagree with the suggestion and agree with the observation it would sacrifice quality and diversity for the sake of 'quick' growth that may be unsustainable.     

The older requirements made sense for a smaller user base and showed as the site grew that the requirements needed to be raised in order to prevent excessive guild creation 'power user' issues and empty/dead guilds.     

Lowering the requirements with a now much larger user base would incentivize the exact issue you're complaining about. New users would make post following the current political trend versus providing secondary view points or new/additional content for the site just for the sake of fast guild creation. Along with making it easier there would be a lack of accomplishment, dedication to running created guilds, and eventual lack of 'respect/appreciation' for guildmasters having put any 'real effort' into creating or growing a community.     

An example of this in action is the amount of game development guilds that currently exist and the level of members/participation:   
  
+gamedev , +GameDevelopers , +GameDevelopment

Posts being made currently that are stuck in general for lack of a guild/community add flavor and view points that might otherwise not be seen due to people dividing up quickly and participating guilds only. If political posts are too abundant for an apolitical person, then it should be the effort of apolitical users to create more apolitical posts to help balance that issue out. The option of guild siege already exists as well.     

Examples of guild that need more participation from varied view points versus political focus or excessive additional guild creation:     

+webcomics , +comics     

* Is it difficult to get the rep needed to make a guild? Yes.
* Should it be difficult? Yes.
* Are there ways to work around that requirement without lowering it? Yes.

post.body:
I've seen a lot of upvoted threads complaining about the prevalence of politics on this site recently (whether that matters has already been discussed to death), but with the relatively high rep requirements for creating a guild, I'm wondering whether there's a bit of a catch 22 situation here:

- For an apolitical person to create a guild, they need to build rep by posting and receiving upvotes.

- The threads and comments which tend to generate rep quickly are political, and anyone who isn't interested in participating will have a long slog ahead of them - especially if they're migrating from Reddit and don't want to 'play the game' to pick up from where they left off.

Does anyone else think it would draw more users if it was easier to make guilds, or is that just sacrificing quality in a rush to the finish line?

Also is it possible for a person who *does* meet rep requirements to create a guild on someone's behalf then hand over full ownership? I might try starting a thread for 'kickstarter' guild requests if so and see how that goes.

Does anyone else think it would draw more users if it was easier to make guilds, or is that just sacrificing quality in a rush to the finish line?

body: I like the rule as-is, because it encourages interaction with Ruqqus. Want to create a guild? Well first you have to help grow others by posting and commenting. I think more comments in less guilds gives new users the impression that there are active users on here.

body:
Posts and comments are the life-blood of a site like this so asking that new users do their bit to bring the site to life instead of just retreating to their quiet corners seems like a good bootstrapping strategy to me.

But you've got a good point about having to be political when you just want to make a non-political guild. Unless some kind of *"wholesome post - great job +5"* super upvote gets implemented, I think the best way to work with this is to unsubscribe from all political guilds and focus on bringing quieter guilds to life. 

There are currently guilds with 100s of members but only a handful of posts - meaning there are lots of users just waiting to see something. Make use of this situation while it lasts - there's easy rep to be had right now.

post.body:
I've seen a lot of upvoted threads complaining about the prevalence of politics on this site recently (whether that matters has already been discussed to death), but with the relatively high rep requirements for creating a guild, I'm wondering whether there's a bit of a catch 22 situation here:

- For an apolitical person to create a guild, they need to build rep by posting and receiving upvotes.

- The threads and comments which tend to generate rep quickly are political, and anyone who isn't interested in participating will have a long slog ahead of them - especially if they're migrating from Reddit and don't want to 'play the game' to pick up from where they left off.

Does anyone else think it would draw more users if it was easier to make guilds, or is that just sacrificing quality in a rush to the finish line?

Also is it possible for a person who *does* meet rep requirements to create a guild on someone's behalf then hand over full ownership? I might try starting a thread for 'kickstarter' guild requests if so and see how that goes.

body: What's not true? The fact that with more guilds it's harder to be visible? That can't be wrong, the more of anything there are the least one of them will be visible. Reddit mods make it so that you cant grow guilds that aren't theirs, sure, but you cant grow a subreddit to a 100 (or atleast it's nearly impossible) either and that's not their work it's the work of an oversaturation of subreddits. If most people can make guilds there will be more guilds making each one of them harder to grow, especially at the beginning.
